region:

country:
None
text:
I love this recipe, and I had been searching for a good French toast recipe for a while.  This one is the winner of all those I've tried.  We used Texas Toast type bread and it came out delicious.  A few notes: You must mix/whisk the egg mixture before dipping new bread in the mixture, because the cinnamon rises to the top and will disappear with your first few slices made if you don't kep mixing as you go.  Also, I find that Butter Flavor Crisco works well for frying these; it produces an even golden appearance and when new butter is added to the hot pan as you make successive pieces, it does not burn/get dark like butter or margarine can.  (I also use Butter Crisco to make grilled cheese.  Sounds weird, maybe, but tastes and looks great.)  I also added a little nutmeg to the mixture the second time I made this.  The leftover French toast can be stored in the fridge or freezer and reheats well (nice and crispy on the outside) in the toaster.

text:
This recipe is wonderful.  I made French Toast with this recipe and froze it with wax paper between each slice and it made really quick and easy breakfast for my teenagers, they just tossed them in the microwave and they were as good as freshly made.

The milk mixture does need to be stirred up frequently because the flour does tend to settle on the bottom of the bowl.

text:
This is the only way I'll make my french toast.  It tastes like a restaurant's.  The flour is the secret.  Instead of adding cinnamon to the batter, I dip the bread, flip, sprinkle with cinnamon, put on the griddle (cinnamon side down), and sprinkle on the other side.  I love it with cinnamon.

text:
Wow, LOVED this recipe!  In reading a LOT of reviews last night, the common theme seemed to be to double the vanilla and the cinnamon so I did, and I also took another reviewer's suggestion and added a Tablespoon of brown sugar, along with the Tablespoon of white sugar.  The results were PERFECT!!  Just got done eating some for breakfast this morning and had to post a review right away, so good!!!  UPDATE (5/30/12):  This recipe is now a FAMILY FAVORITE!  I use Texas Toast and found that if you triple this recipe, it will make 2 loaves (30 slices) total.  I make it this way and then freeze all the slices that don't get eaten at breakfast... would you believe that these taste even BETTER after they've been frozen??  I just pop them in the toaster until they are heated through and they are PERFECT!  A great tasty homemade quick breakfast... these are now a staple in our freezer!  My kids love to eat these as french toast sticks.  After I reheat them, I cut them into 4 or 5 strips and then they dip them in maple syrup.  UPDATE (12/19/13):  Just when I didn't think this recipe could get any better, I used Kirkland (Costco) brand Cinnamon bread... AMAZING!!!

text:
This recipe got rave reviews from everyone (including my best friend's little 2 year old :-P). The flavor and texture were perfect. I had day old Challah on hand which I was thrilled about, because that's the secret to making perfect French toast. Next time you make these, definitely use Challah and not just any old bread. That's how the restaurants get it so perfect, and that's the secret to making it like they do. Also, let it soak up all the liquid... the more liquid it soaks up, the better it tastes. I'll certainly be making these again!

text:
OMG! I love french toast and thought that my recipe was great until I tried this one. The addition of flour made me curious to try it and I'm glad that I did. It really made a difference. In my opinion this recipe is way better than the restaurants. I pretty much followed the instructions although I eye balled the measurement of the ingredients and omitted the salt. The toast turned out golden brown on the outside, moist and fluffy on the inside...As others mentioned you have to let your bread soak briefly in the mixture to absorb some of the liquid flavor. DON'T just dunk and take out immediately. To avoid soggy toast do not cook too fast on high heat. Cook on medium heat until golden brown on each side...After the toast are done I usually sift powered sugar on top and serve with warm syrup. The presentation just looks pretty.

text:
Perfect French toast and so easy to customize to one's own family preferences.  For a little more "oomph", I occasionally add Grand Marnier and use a thick raisin bread...  As other reviewers have noted, you need to stir the egg mixture from time to time as the cinnamon and flour settle to the bottom and let the toast soak up the egg so the full flavor comes through.  HELPFUL HINTS:  Try serving this with a scoop of warmed apple pie filling spooned on top or add a caramel glaze (1/2 cup butter, 1/2 cup brown sugar, 1/4 cup cream, 1/2 teaspoon of vanilla on a slow boil for 4 minutes) or Isybel's "Blueberry Sauce" from this site.  All are equally as good and wonderful with this French toast recipe.  Enjoy!

text:
The flour didn't make it fluffy, it just made it tough on the outside.  My usual recipe and method makes truly fluffy and crispy french toast (1 cup milk, 6 eggs, 1 tblsp orange juice - fry the toast in 1/4 inch hot oil until golden brown).  A tip for getting the cinnamon mixed in: whisk it and the sugar into the flour before adding the milk.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been making this french toast for years, and this recipe is the best, I think because of the flour. What I do is buy a pkg of Rhodes dough for rolls, thaw out 12 of them, cut them into quarters, roll in cinnamon sugar and drop them into a greased loaf pan. I let that rise until it comes to the top of the loaf pan and then bake it according to pkg directions. I do this the day before so it has time to harden up a bit. I slice it thick and it usually gives me about 8 slices. One note...if you do your bread a couple slices at a time, you do need to whisk each time before you soak new bread, because the flour falls to the bottom. Also, I like to soak the bread slices that I'll be cooking next, and then let them rest on a plate. It comes out better.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
First, this recipe needs to be doubled in order to make more than 8+ slices of thick French toast. Also, it is a bit bland for my taste-I prefer a sweeter custard. So, here are my changes: 2-1/2 c 2% milk, 5 eggs & 3 egg whites, 1/3 c fine granulated sugar, 1/2 c complete pancake mix, 2 tsp. vanilla, 1 tsp. cinnamon (+ more to sprinkle on as needed) and 1 tsp. nutmeg. I whisked everything together then put in the refrigerator over night. I used a very crusty, thick Greek white bread: dipped each side in custard for 30 seconds, let sit on a wire rack for 2 minutes then cooked on a griddle until light brown. Finally, I finished them off by baking in a 375 degree preheated oven for 5-6 minutes. So, overall this was an easy basic recipe to start with and modify to taste.

text:
This did make for fluffier french toast, but I like mine sweeter, so next time I will be doubling the sugar.  Here is my handy tip for making the absolutely fluffiest french toast.  Cook your french toast in a skillet with a lid.  After dropping the french toast in the skillet, cover with the lid for a couple of minutes until the first side is brown. Uncover to flip.  Then recover to cook the remaining side.  This turns your frying pan into a mini "oven", so the french toast essentially "bakes" in the pan.  If you don't have a skillet with a cover, make it on your griddle, and cover it with a metal bowl.  This will have a similar effect.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This made yummy french toast. I usually never use a recipe for making this breakfast dish, but I read the reviews and decided to try it since I wanted "restaurant-style" FT. I followed the recipe as written, though I did use a little less sugar than called for, and I did add some orange extract (can also use zest) for some extra oomph. Overall, it came out very tasty, though I would make it again with some minor modifications to indulge my personal FT preferences. 

I took a reviewer's recommendation and fried the FT in butter-flavored Crisco, which, as she mentioned did not burn when I added more to the griddle (huge plus!!) and made the slices fry up picture-perfect. However,  I did miss the real butter flavor (and smell) that comes from frying in deliciously decadent butter. :-) 

Next time I make it, I will 1) use real butter; 2) sprinkle extra cinnamon on each slice just before frying (as noted by another reviewer, cinnamon in batter tends to sink toward bottom); and 3) use an extra egg and reduce milk to 3/4 cup. I prefer my FT batter more egg-y than this recipe turned out to be. 

Note: this recipe, as written, yielded enough batter for six, well-soaked pieces of Arnold Whole Grain White bread.

This is my favorite recipe for French toast, because it doesn't produce a lot of waste, and because personally I think it tastes better than the recipes that have more eggs and no flour. It's less soggy because a lot of the liquid sticks to the flour, and so it stays on the outside and cooks up, rather than soaking in and becoming a wet mess. Thanks for sharing your recipe!

userID:
5505496
Display Name:
Gretchen Anne
isPro:
False
followersCount:
2

0

2
favoritesCount:
2
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6300710.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
For everyone who does not like this recipe here are a few hints to make it better. First no matter what kind of bread you use it will work better if it is stale or left out over night, if you dont have stale bread put it in the oven on the lowest heat for a couple minutes before it turns brown. Second  MAKE SURE YOU ADD THE MILK AFTER THE FLOUR AND POUR SLOW THEN WISK, POUR SLOW THEN WISK, UNTIL YOU HAVE NO MORE MILK LEFT this will keep it from looking like cottage cheese. Third to avoid it getting super soggy it is best to cook on a low/medium heat (stove) or 300 on a griddle and do not rush, only flip it one time. Hope this helps.
Review:
Rating:

text:
Good recipe w/addition of flour.  I add an egg or two, double the vanilla and cut back on milk to keep it rich in custard-like flavor.  Instead of adding spices to the batter,  I sprinkle the cinnamon & nutmeg over slices as they cook on griddle.  More even distribution this way.  I generally use sour dough bread "extra" sour if available.  Thanks!!!

country:
None
text:
I experimented with this recipe using plain white bread and it turned out well even though my boyfriend wasn't impressed- he felt it tasted no diferent from his which is just plain egg.    BUT since the batter was so much (we only ate 3 slices), I added more milk+brown sugar+cinnamon, cut up a thick herbed Arabian bread-bun and soaked in the batter...it smells wonderful!Soft and spongy with slightly crispy burnt edges. I plan to reheat/grill this later for a snack with some cheddar cheese,oregano and fresh tomatoes.And maybe scrambled eggs and baked beans if I'd like a heavier meal.    Lately my fridge has become too full and I don't know if the batter will keep well.To my delight, I found the recipe for French crepes in this site..virtually the same recipe, just had to tweak it a little- added more flour...and the result was some nice crepes! So just using this base, I've had sweet cinnamon French toast (with peanut butter + strawberry jelly..but better plain) and 1 large crepe (savoury cos I like mine with Bovril)

text:
I really enjoyed this french toast. I've never added sugar or flour to french toast before and because of the sweetness from the sugar I didn't even need syrup and it tasted great on it's own. Something else I noticed was that the mixture was more evenly mixed then my usual recipe. Normally by the time I get to the last couple of pieces it's just the thick egg whites left behind and the french toast comes out very "eggy" but I didn't get that with this recipe. Everything was so smooth and well blended. I think the flour may have contributed to that. This will be my french toast recipe from now on.

text:
Very tasty recipe!  I used two types of bread and dipped it into this batter.  One was French baguettes, sliced at  inch, and the other was store-bought cinnamon bread.  Word of caution:  Do not let the bread slices saturate too long in the batter.  Otherwise, after frying them, the center of the bread would still be a bit soggy in texture.  The French baguettes were my personal favorite because of the thickness and less dense texture.  I like my French toast to taste more eggy so I might want to add an extra egg in the future.

text:
Like a lot of other reviewers, I had been searching for a good french toast recipe for a long time. I always found ones that left the french toast soggy or lacking the rich flavor like in the restaurants. I finally found it! Flour is the key. I didnt change a thing! My picky preschoolers LOVED it and thats the best taste test there is in this house! Make sure you wisk the mixture with each bread slice so you get the cinammon coat and also, I added a bit more cinnamon to each side when drying. EXCELLENT!

I chose to give this recipe a try as many have said the added flour helps to keep the toast light instead of wet and soggy. The texture turned out very light and even a little crispy around the edges. The cinnamon was the perfect amount and the tip to make sure to give the mix a stir every time a new piece is dipped is an important one to keep in mind. I had made some challah bread the day before and found it to work beautifully in this dish. Thanks so much for posting.

I've always had a problem with french toast turning out too eggy and mushy for my taste; I guess the flour must be the trick, because this turned out just the way I like it.  I scaled it down to make two pieces for just myself, used wheat bread as that's all I had, and just eyeballed the cinnamon, vanilla and such.  I also added a little nutmeg.  I have no syrup, so I drizzled both pieces with honey, added brown sugar to one and powdered sugar to the other, and ate both with some sliced banana.  Mmmm. Thanks! I'll use this recipe for french toast from now on.

text:
I have a suggestion for those who had trouble getting the cinnamon to mix and with the flour settling, I put the ingredients in the blender and mixed for a few seconds.  Its makes the mixture turn out very smooth, however you do have to add a more cinnamon and sugar to get a flavor with the same intensity.  All the slices will have the same amount of flavor instead of the first few picking up all the cinnamon.

text:
I adjusted the serving size to four and followed the direction exactly other than I used regular white bread. Even with the whisk, it was lumpy, and once I soaked two pieces of bread (one serving), I was about out of mixture to dip into, so the entire 12 serving recipe would make 3 servings. Once on the non-stick griddle, it stuck and took way longer than usual to cook. After more than 10 minutes on the griddle, it was completely soggy in the middle. The second batch I cooked (with cooking spray) for more than 15 minutes. Completely soggy in the middle. Also VERY BLAND. The cinnamon and sugar need to be doubled, at least.

text:
I've made this several times now and it has been a success every time.  I also have reduced it for just two of us.  I use a "super bread" which I get at our farmer's market - has raisins, cranberries, walnuts, seeds - and this works great with this.  For three slices, which I cut in half after cooking, i use 1T flour, 1/4 c. milk, scant pinch salt, 1 egg, 1/16 t. cinnamon, 1/4 t. vanilla, 1/4 t. sugar.  Excellent.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
A well earned 5 stars. It was a good combination of ingredients with the Flour being a key ingredient, as mentioned by a previous reviewer.

I used 3/4 of the recipe (8 servings), according to the calculator on the page, but not everything was divided down to 3/4 of the original quantities/amounts as it actually yielded less mixture for the number of servings.

I followed what the calculator suggested, but I ended up increasing the Flour, Cinnamon, Salt & Vanilla Extract. It should have yielded 8 servings (8 slices), but I only got 5 servings, which was actually just right for me and the wife (we went 50/50). I cooked the toast with Butter. I topped them with Powdered Sugar and 100% Maple Syrup. Thanks to Bonnie for listing her recipe! :^)

Ingredients:
   3 tbsp Flour
2/3 cup Milk
1/4 tsp Salt
   2 Eggs
   1 tbsp ground Cinnamon
   1 tbsp Vanilla Extract
   2 tbsp granulated Sugar
   5 slices of Bread

Optional:
Powdered Sugar
Maple Syrup

None
text:
This french toast was excellent. soft (not mushy) and flavorful. I only changed two things. I added two tablespoons of sugar to the batter (instead of one), and I used day old Texas Toast. By the way, if your toast isn't day old, pop it in the oven on 350 until it is crunchy, but not toasted. All you need is to take the moisture out of the bread. Leaving it out for a day will take out the moisture slowly, but if you forgot or don't have time, just pop it in the oven. 

Thanks Bonnie!

text:
I have never actually followed a recipe for french toast. I usually just do it from my head. My recipe is the same pretty much, but this one added flour. I changed the servings to 4 and it worked fine. The taste was good as it seemed to keep a little more liquid in the bread, with the flour, so it gave it flavor throughout. And, it gave it a slight crispiness I don't normally get by not adding the flour. The one thing that has to be changed is to generously butter the griddle, because my french toast stuck badly. The flour acted like a glue to the pan until the side was fully cooked. And, I had lightly oiled only as suggested. However, I think I will follow this recipe again because of the extra flavor I noticed.

userID:
1246951
Display Name:
WALKINGTEE
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
5
favoritesCount:
19

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is excellent.  The small addition of flour and sugar really helps the browning, giving it a crisp exterior while the interior nice and light without any sogginess.  The recipe writer has really earned accolades.  Now, to solve the problems noted by some reviewers:  1. The problem of cinnamon settling to the bottom -- yes, the ground cinnamon does clump together, making it sink.  To prevent this, blend the ingredients in a blender, food processor, or with a stick blender.  The cinnamon will distribute more evenly than with a whisk or eggbeater.  If you leave the mixture sitting for any length of time, re-blend before dipping the bread. 2.  Not enough cinnamon flavor -- Mix the batter the night before and refrigerate, the flavors should intensify. Re-blend before using. (see above). Always use fresh cinnamon (not stuff that has been in your kitchen for a year.)  Also double the cinnamon or sprinkle each slice separately. 3.  Sogginess -- If you are getting soggy French Toast with this recipe, it is not the fault of the reipe. Here are a few thing you might do better: a.  Use thick slices of slightly stale or dried bread --  Texas toast style is best.  If the bread is fresh, dry it a bit in a warm oven.  b.  Saturated the bread, do not soak it in the egg mixture. Each side of bread should sit in the egg mixture for a few seconds only.  c.  Use a hot skillet or griddle with about 1/4" hot oil (Crisco is best, but canola is ok).  Replenish oil as needed between slices.

Rating:
3
dateLastModified:

text:
It really does taste like the restaurants! The only flour I had on hand was white whole wheat and it worked out great. I used a sourdough loaf and cut my slices about an inch thick or so. I did let them soak the batter on each side for a while plus I poked my slices with a fork for better absorption. The only change I made was to double the cinnamon and add in 1/2 tsp of nutmeg. This was so easy to put together, the longest part of it was the cooking. If I was in a hurry I would've cut my slices a bit more thin, it took about 4-5 min on each side with a lid on my pan at med-low heat. You can freeze the leftovers like one cook suggested and use a toaster to reheat but with my thickness I had to choose the Frozen Bagel setting and turn it to #5 on the dial. Something to keep in mind if you're in a hurry in the mornings.   I'm keeping this recipe, definitely doing it again and recommending it to anyone who likes/loves French Toast!!

text:
I was in the mood for French Toast this morning and found this recipe.  It was wonderful and has made a permanent home in my recipe box.  I did read the reviews of before I started, and noted that there were some who had issues with the flour.  I substitued "Wondra" flour (made by Gold Medal) for regular flour.  It's very fine texture made it easy to blend with the milk.  I also tripled the use of vanilla and added a tablespoon of Cinnamon.  I used "Texas Toast" for my bread.  It came out super fluffy and to spite some of the other reviews, did NOT come out tasting of flour.  The great thing about this recipe is that you can add a little of this and a little of that and make it your own.  Big Kudos on adding the flour.  It was just enough to make the consistance more batter like, rather than soup like.  Very tasty!

text:
It's been a long time since I've had french toast...one of the reasons I don't have it often is because a lot of the recipes make the toast taste too 'eggy' for me.   I like this one because I didn't have to use a lot of eggs plus the flour thickened the batter without having to add extra eggs.   I just mixed all of the dry ingredients together and then whisked in the eggs, vanilla, and milk-the batter still turned out great.   One variation you might want to try is to use sour milk in place of the regular milk..it thickens up the batter a bit and adds a little 'oomph' in my opinion.   Thanks for getting me back to eating french toast again :-)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my go to recipe for french toast.  I get raves every time I make it.  My kid requested pumpkin pie french toast one morning so I used this recipe as a base and added 1/8 t. nutmeg, 1/8 t. cloves, and 1/4 t. ginger, substituted the sugar with 2 T. brown sugar and used 3/4 c. milk and 1/4 cup pumpkin puree and it worked out magically.  Just make sure to cook the bread on medium heat, if you cook it too fast, the outside will brown quickly without cooking the inside.  They are little pillows of perfection.

text:
Normally I make my french toast with just egg and milk nothing else.  Usually my toast came out kinda flat and flavorless.  LOL.  Tried this recipe and loved it!  I also added some nutmeg to it.  Yum!  Never thought adding a bit of flour would help make them fluffy.  I learned to make french toast from my mom who really didn't experiment a whole lot mostly because of my dad and he's picky.  Since I got married 10 years ago I have gotten more "experimental" and tried my own things and have had success.  Don't be afraid to add your own thing.  I know some reviewers hate on people who change the recipes.  There is usually a reason.  Most people are looking for a base recipe and then go from there especially after reading reviews on what works for others.  I've posted recipes on here myself and I WELCOME people changing my recipes to suit their own tastes.  Why be boring?  LOL.  Anyways great recipe.  Thank you Bonnie!

text:
We had this for dinner tonite and everyone enjoyed it.  I had to use regular sandwich bread as that is all I had on hand although I agree that Texas toast or a good French or Italian loaf would've been better.  Next time I will double the recipe, as I didn't even really let the bread soak and I only had enough mixture for 11 pieces of bread.  I also used a tablespoon of brown sugar in addition to the white sugar as another reviewer had suggested. I also cooked the bread slices in butter flavor crisco as well, which was also recommended by another reviewer. Next time I will be sure to soak each piece of bread for a longer time as the one piece that I did soak longer was the best one and did fluff up nicely.  Thanks so much for sharing this recipe....I know my family will use it a lot!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a really good recipe! I followed another commenter's advice and sprinkled cinnamon on each side once putting it in the pan, because as is I didn't feel it was cinnamon-y enough, hence the 4 stars. But that is just my preference. With the adjustment it was delicious! I also added xylitol in place of sugar as well as nutmeg to the wet mix, and instead of using butter or Crisco to fry with, I used ghee, which is clarified butter and has a higher smoke point. Then you don't have to worry about burnt butter smell, and reap all the health benefits of delicious ghee! Next day leftovers are even better, as someone said before, u can just pop them in the toaster and they are good to go! My new favorite go-to breakfast!

text:
The reason I am giving this recipe five stars is that's tasty and healthy at the same time. I've been making a french toast recipe for years that is awesome, but it is loaded in fat and calories. I recently had my galbladder out, and that has made me re-evaluate what I eat. This recipe has less than 200 calories and has 2.7 grams of fat. This means that I can have one piece of bacon, piece of fruit, and this recipe and I am still under 400 calories and feel full. This recipe is a definite keeper!

text:
This recipe is THE best for french toast.  It makes french toast the way it should be, fluffy, moist (not soggy) and flavorful!  I have made this recipe several times and it's my family's favorite.  I always use french loaf and can double the recipe to 24 slices.  They freeze very well and reheat great.  My only change to the recipe is to add a dash of nutmeg.  Just a personal taste preference.  If you've never used nutmeg just know it is strong so a little goes a long way!  You must try this recipe. You will not be disappointed!

Recipe made about 3/4 of the servings listed.  Mixed dry ingredients first and then added wet ingredients ~ made a difference on how well they blended.  Letting slices soak while others cooked was a bad idea for "average" bread ~ it starting falling apart.  Besides that, my kids loved that this non-cooking Mom cooked french toast for the 1st time and even sprinkled it with powdered sugar!  :-)

text:
Needed a quick dinner for my daughter and me tonight, and since I was craving french toast, this fit the bill. I mixed my dry ingredients (flour, sugar, salt, and cinnamon) into the wet ones (milk, eggs, and vanilla) and whisked away. I added a tad more vanilla, a splash of almond extract, as I like the taste, and used 2 T sugar. All I had on hand was wheat bread, which worked great, but I'd love to try it with Texas toast next!

text:
It was great- at least from what I can tell. (I have a week to loose 7-10 lbs and am avoiding carbs.) My 4 year-old had two slices and her 2 year-old brother scarfed up 3.  I mixed all the dry ingredients well first, then added the milk/vanilla mixture slowly until well-blended, adding the eggs last. The cinnamon  was well mixed and did not rise to the top-the last slice had just as much cinnamon as the first. I used butter on a griddle over low heat and allowed each side to cook about 4 minutes or until nicely browned.

text:
These are tasty and worth the effort.  I used day old buns sliced thick and I allowed the slices to soak up the mixture.  Cook on med-low - don't rush them or they don't cook through the middle.  Notably flavourful and they smell wonderful.  Two 13 year old boys ate all and looked for more.  I do wonder how this recipe calls for 12 slices of bread - my mixture would only have done about 6 slices (2 and half buns was all I could do from one batch of mix.)

text:
This recipe takes the ordinary french toast to extraordinary. I did as the fellow reviewer did and added a pinch of baking powder and a couple shacks of nutmeg. Totally delicious!! The nutmeg adds a kick to it. Also the first two slices of toast I did were not as fluffy as I liked, but then I realized it was because I was not letting them soak enough. All I needed to do was let them soak for a couple more second and that did the trick, came out more fluffy and thick, which made it amazing!
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2012-01-14T11:41:06.37
helpfulCount:

userID:
2317510
Display Name:
MagnoliaSouth
isPro:
False
followersCount:
3
followingCount:

35
favoritesCount:
83
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1182240.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is pretty good, but I can't tell the difference between this and French Toast I (though I tweaked both, more on this one in a minute). Most importantly: it is NOT fluffy. Not sure where that comes from. Flour doesn't fluff. The truth is, most French Toast recipes are similar and it's all just a matter of taste. I've made it this way several times, I've made it without flour, I've made it with more egg and I've made it with less milk and so forth. For this though, I doubled the cinnamon and vanilla and put in about 3/4 tsp of nutmeg (which could go up to 1 tsp). You DO NOT need thick bread to make this either. It's great for your stale/old regular sandwich bread. I do however recommend that if you're using regular bread, and it isn't stale, to let it sit out for about an hour or so to stiffen up (maybe in the oven overnight too) - to prevent sogginess - and don't soak regular bread either. Just dip it in and shake it off. In my opinion, making it with regular bread has more flavor than with thick bread. I have a little jar that I've covered with NEW (right out of the container) cleaned screen (yep, regular window screening), and in it is my powdered sugar. If you're guests are pouring their own syrup, then add it before giving it to them. If you're pouring it on there then add it after you've added the syrup. It melts into the syrup so you want them to see the sugar.

text:
This was a very good recipe but I have one suggestion. I dont think the amount of the ingredients for the egg wash is adequate for the servings.  So, for whatever number of servings you calculate, I recommend you double the ingredients. While you may have some egg wash left over, I feel its better not to run out in the middle of cooking for your guests. Since the bread should be totally saturated, you wont have to worry about running out if you double it.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This turned out great!  I used 15 slices of texas toast so when I got close to finishing 12 slices I just added 1 more egg and maybe 1/2 - 3/4 C. of milk.  After dipping the first 3-4 slices of bread, the mixture was short on cinnamon (I even whisked the mixture after each slice based on the reviews from others).  I would dip the remainder of the bread in the mixture, sprinkle cinnamon on one side and lay that side face down on the griddle and then sprinkle cinnamon on the other side (I also got this idea from a previous review).  After the french toast was cooked and placed on a serving platter I sifted powdered sugar over the top.  It tasted great & had a beautfiul presentation!  I froze the leftovers so we could have a quick & easy breakfast during the week.  My husband already tried some this morning before work and he said it was great.  We will be using this recipe again, thank you!

text:
Best french toast I ever made!!!  Read the reviews that said adding baking powder makes them truly fluffy; then decided to do it my way.  In place of the flour I used 1/3 cup extra fluffy pancake mix.  I increased to 1/3 cup to get more of the baking powder action, and to compensate for the egss/milk/etc in the mix.  They were awesome.  Used texas toast, put it on a rack in a 200F oven and turned it off and let sit several hours to dry the bread.  Only had enough batter to do 8 slices, but it was awesome!!

Awesome recipe / taste, followed the ingredients exactly, I will make again!  My bread was a LITTLE wet in the middle and I just did a quick dip, so that probably has more to do with my personal cooking technique.  Another reviewer suggested to cover the pan while cooking so I will attempt that.  I see that other people have had trouble with making the mix stretch...I made 8 slices from a regular sliced loaf and still had mix left to dip the bread in.  Update:  Covering the pan definitely works better.  I never have old bread on hand and found that this recipe works very well with store brand Texas toast bread.  Worth trying with the Blueberry Breakfast Sauce from this site.  Yum!

This was great. I made it this morning for breakfast. I usually have a problem with french toast instantly getting soggy. I did notice in the end that when I poured out the excess the flour had settled to the bottom so I think it is really important to whisk it each time.

text:
This recipe is very delicious. Just a few notes: make sure you SOAK the bread because we sort of dipped for about ten seconds and the French Toast was kind of dry because we didn't soak the bread long enough.  Also we put in one pureed banana.  Make sure to stir the batter after soaking every couple of slices because flour goes to the bottom and cinnamon goes to the top.  We used our super market bakery home-style white bread.  The French Toast was very delicious.  Love them so much.

text:
I doubled the cinnamon like other reviewers suggested.  I like each slice to be equally saturated with the egg mixture so I arranged my bread in a jelly roll pan and poured the mixture over all the pieces at once.  I let it sit a few minutes and flipped the bread so the tops could soak up the remaining liquid.  I fried the bread on a non-stick griddle with no extra oil or butter and the results came out great.  Definitely a keeper.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a fantastic recipe! I have never had much luck making French toast before.  All the ones I made turned out just okay, but the ones I made using this recipe were fluffy and tasty.  They smelled lovely too.  I followed the recipe exactly, but I did reduce the vanilla because I know that I often find the extract too strong for my personal preference.  I used the bread from Chinese style bakery, which is slightly more moist and moist.  It's a bit like egg bread.  I do have one little tip to share - Cinnamon floats, so the first two slices tend to suck up all the cinnamon.  After the first few slices, add an extra pinch of cinnamon and stir up the mixture to ensure that the remaining slices are just as cinnamony.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious and very quick and easy. The best two tips I read from others were
1. whisk the mixture before dipping the next piece of bread, and 2. use butter flavored Crisco (butter burns and turns brown too quickly!) Make sure to cook it 2-3 mins on each side so you don't get stuck with soggy french toast. If it's burning by then your skillet is up too high! :) Enjoy!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm a novice cook and I made this before and it was only ok.  It was a bit on the soggy side.  But, I tried it again and this time it was awesome.  The key for me was that I needed to make sure the bread was crispy before removing it from the pan.  It would look golden brown as the recipe states, but it would be too soggy for me.  Once I left it on the pan longer and tested the crispiness by touching it with a spatula, it was perfect!  Perhaps that's what most people already do, but again, being a novice cook, I had to learn through trial and error.

None
text:
excellent french toast! Simply delicious! I do have a suggestion though. next time I would sprinkle the cinnamon onto the bread after it has been soaked in the liquid mixture. This way there is more of a detectable cinnamon taste and each piece of bread gets evenly spiced rather then the first couple pieces soaking up all the cinnamon. And this is my personal preference, but I love sprinkling brown sugar onto the   bread as it's frying. It gives a sweet hint so that I don't necessarily have to use too much syrup later.

text:
This was very good!  I took the suggestion of a past reviewer and mixed everything in the blender - much easier to get the flour mixed in!  Also I used powdered buttermilk in place of regular milk and doubled the cinnamon.  It has a thicker texture and isn't so soggy like regular french toast.  Be prepared to cook a bit longer on lower heat so it gets cooked through.

None
text:
My family agrees this is the best French toast I've ever made!  I took some suggestions from other reviewers and used butter Crisco on the griddle, added brown sugar (kept the white sugar too), and doubled the vanilla.  I also added butter extract to make it even richer tasting, and sprinkled a little powdered sugar on before serving to make it look pretty.   I used 2 loaves of Texas toast bread and quadrupled the recipe; I had leftover egg mixture so I may have been able to just triple it, but I wanted to be sure I had enough.  Kept leftovers in the fridge overnight and reheated them in the toaster oven on 350 til warm.  Yummy the second day too.

region:

country:
None
text:
I was a little dubious about adding flour to the batter for French toast, but, boy, I'm glad I did. This recipe did, in fact, produce one of the fluffiest FTs I've ever made in my life. I adhered to the recipe almost entirely, but I did add some extra vanilla extract because I like it. Other that than, I kept to the original. With that in mind, however, I do recommend that you use a good quality bread. It makes a world of difference. Sandwich bread just wouldn't cut it. You really need to have a thick bread that can absorb the liquid without falling apart. In my case, I had some soft french bread on hand that I got at my local grocery store. I CANNOT RECOMMEND THIS RECIPE ENOUGH. IT'S MY NEW GO-TO FRENCH TOAST.

userID:

Display Name:
lia 
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Amazing!!! I finally found a good french toast recipe. To really perfect it I used only the egg yolks instead of the entire egg and I baked the toast after cooking in the skillet. Set it at 350 deg for at most 10 minutes to make the outside crunchy but not burnt and retain a soft inside. The bread you pick will definitely make it, so stop by the bakery section of your local grocery store and grab a loaf you can slice yourself to the desired thickness. Cut your bread the day (or night) before and leave it out, it'll get stale enough to soak up your french toast mixture.

text:
This is the only recipe for French toast I use my husband and son won't eat anyone's or anywhere else's ! I omit the salt and add extra vanilla and cinnamon! I serve with homemade cinnamon syrup and other times I throw some raspberries, blackberries , or strawberries which ever I have that day in a sauce pan with some water , sugar, and flour and make a nice fruit topping jam  !! These freeze well to and reheat in the toaster still as delicious as freshly made !!

text:
I have been using the modified version of this recipe in my Cafe now.  I did add nutmeg at the ratio of 3:1 of cinnamon..so 3 tsp. cinnamon to 1 tsp nutmeg.  I used brown sugar instead of white sugar along with doubling the vanilla.  I also lowered the flower content by 1/3rd.  It is a very well balanced french toast recipe as written but with these changes it was super awesome and a customer favorite.

text:
My family really did love this recipe.  I couldn't find a thick sliced bread at the grocery I go to so I ended up using some potato bread slices.  Only thing I changed was added some nutmeg (personal choice and really the seasonings can be adjusted to any preferences). Some reviewers have commented that while fluffy the middle turned out dry.  Most of mine turned out that way as well, but I personally like a dryer middle vs a soggy or mushy one.  I loved how fluffy it turned  out vs the dense traditional of the method I previously used.  As others have stated Make Sure You Stir the Batter Before Each Use!  It does settle and quite quickly.  Very glad I came across this recipe. Thank you for sharing it!

text:
Best French toast ever! I used "day old" french bread cut on the diagonal (WAY better than regular bread or Texas toast). Also, I grated cinnamon sticks for the cinnamon. Not necessary, but it smelled, looked, and tasted better. At the end I sprinkled finely ground sea salt and powdered sugar on top, with syrup. The sweet and salty combo made it pop. I used unsalted butter to cook them in, so maybe you skip that if using salted butter. This came out better than ANY restaurant I have been to.

Display Name:
Bradley

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4291140.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Hands down the best French toast recipe I've ever tried.  I added my own little flair to it, but I've made the original recipe, too, and loved it. My alterations are as follows: I use French bread. I buy the $1 loaf at Walmart and cut it up into thick slices. It comes out to about 16 pieces. Next, I use vanilla sugar. Don't do this unless you're a fan of vanilla. You could cut back on the vanilla extract if necessary. I do not. I also use real maple syrup. It's so much better than the imitation stuff. It's expensive but worth it.

Overall, this is an A++ recipe. It's easy to make; delicious; and a crowd pleaser. Try it.

text:
Loved this recipe! I increased the cinnamon to 1 tsp but left everything else the same. Turns out great every time I make it. Make sure to whisk in between batches or your first few slices will be full of cinnamon and the rest will have none because the cinnamon floats the the top as it sits.

text:
Turned out great!!  Since Im gluten/dairy free, I had to substitute some ingredients. I used an all-purpose gluten free flour and replaced the milk with sweetened almond milk. I also exchanged the white sugar for coconut sugar. I love that this French Toast mixture uses flour which helps to bind the egg mixture to bread a lot better. The thing I thought was abit iffy was the amount of salt used. I decreased the salt amount, but it still tasted alittle salty.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674138.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The Mrs. will only eat the French toast sticks because they are firm and not soggy, much like the French toast that I ate when growing up. However, she loves this recipe more than her beloved French toast sticks. That is of course after I slightly modify the recipe to our preferred taste. As suggested by other reviewers: add 1 tbsp. brown sugar, double the vanilla extract to 2 tsp., double the cinnamon to 1 tsp., add a bit of nutmeg (1/2 tsp.). I also prefer to use 1 to 2 day old/stale texas toast bread and reduce the milk to 3/4 cup. Then, I top them off with butter, confectioners sugar, fresh fruit, and whipped cream. Whole family agrees that this is best French toast recipe to date, even when unaltered.

text:
I just made this recipe for my family's Valentine's Day breakfast.  It is definitely the fluffiest French Toast I've ever made, but the first test batch was lacking flavor for our taste.  For the second batch, I added more cinnamon, vanilla and sugar and the flavor was much better.  I also used Challah bread, cut into 1" thick slices, which soaks up a lot of the mixture so I had to more than double the recipe to have enough.  Thank you for sharing the idea of putting flour into the mix...it definitely makes a big difference.  Topped mine with additional cinnamon sugar and/or confectioners sugar.    Delicious!

This was sooooo good! I woke up New Year's Day wanting something sweet and had a extra loaf of French bread and then found this recipe.  Oh My! I did as some reviewers suggested  and used brown sugar in lieu of the white sugar.  Then I added some extra cinnamon at the end. Will use this again and again.  Extra good with a sprinkling of powdered sugar!

Loved this. I used two day old French bread baked at the local market that I sliced thick (about an inch). I sprinkled a little extra cinnamon on one side of the slices when I put them on the non-stick griddle and they were perfect. I used an electric mixer to mix the ingredients. This tasted like the French Toast my mom used to make. My 3yo loved it too! Of course pure Vermont maple syrup heated and drizzled on top sealed the deal. :-)

text:
Decent recipe but had some issues with the ingredients kind of floating to the top. So the first dipped toast would have everything on there, but the others would have no cinnamon or eggs or anything. So next time definitely wisk between each dipping.

Only had regular (not thick) sliced bread so we used that. Thick would've been nice, but it worked out fine.

Made 6 for me and my hubby, but had to make more of the dip stuff because the recipe cut in half wasn't enough. So just make whole thing and use how many slices you want, unless only making one or two pieces.

text:
This is the same as my old recipe with the exception of the flour. I loved this recipe as it was easy and smelled wonderful. My kids said my house smelled like Disney Main Street Bakery. I used a thick egg bread similar to Texas Toast. I used a hand mixer to make the batter and I still had flour gathering at the bottom. I wonder if you mixed it and let it sit overnight or for a while in the morning so that the flour has time to absorb the liquids if it would be more of a suspension and a batter. Either way it was terrific and fast and freezes beautifully with waxed paper between the slices and then in an air-tight bag. Then in the morning you put it in the toaster and it is perfect.

This was my first time making French toast and this recipe was a big hit!  I doubled the cinnamon and vanilla, and I used heavy cream instead of whole milk.  My family loved it!  My husband almost never eats carbs, but it was so good he even got seconds!  I also used the thick Texas toast and let it really soak up the egg mixture before cooking it on medium heat with coconut oil.  Then I cooked up some sliced bananas in cinnamon, coconut oil, and vanilla, and put it on the French toast.  I will definitely be making this again!

text:
Very tasty and easy! I mixed all the dry ingredients and then whisked in the wet ingredients. Just a tip - the alcohol in the vanilla breaks down the cinnamon, therefore, stir the vanilla and cinnamon together (I used a shot glass) thoroughly and add it to the mixture. Hope this is helpful.

I only had a little bit of milk and one egg left and searched for a breakfast recipe that would fit within those constraints. I discovered this and cut it down to four servings for myself and my two toddlers. Needless to say, this was a big hit! This one is a keeper.

This was a nice change from the traditional egg, milk, cinnamon combo I usually default to. There wasn't a drastic difference but it just tasted better overall. Display Name:
jcn

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674146.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After reading some reviews that claimed the cinnamon tends to disappear and that the flour sinks to the bottom needing the batter to be constantly whisked, I made a few procedural changes and the results were excellent. First, I sifted the flour, salt, and cinnamon into the bowl and whisked that while I slowly added the milk. I then proceeded to add each egg, whisking constantly, and after the second egg added the vanilla and finally brown sugar (which gives the batter a wonderful caramel taste) after the last egg. I used Villagio bread ( a thick white bread) and was able to stretch the batter to 9 slices. Served with organic maple syrup and fresh blueberries and sliced bananas, this was a real weekend breakfast treat.

country:
None
text:
Saturating regular bread in a mix with this much milk led to soggy French toast. Either you need to have thick, firm, dry bread, or just do a quick dip for regular stale bread. Towards the end of my cooking, I added more egg to the mix to see if that helped, and it was much better. Also added a dash of nutmeg for the last few slices which was a good recommendation from another reviewer. Temp on a griddle should be 300-325.

text:
I've made it about a dozen times, and it's been great every time. I recommend honey wheat bread. If you need more servings, add an extra egg. Also, putting the cinnamon on the toast while it's on the griddle works best for making all the slices even. Otherwise, the first slice will have a lot of cinnamon, and the last will have very little.

text:
Perfect french toast! I followed the recipe almost exactly, only left out cinnamon (not a fan) & used turbinado sugar & these turned out great. I made the whole french loaf & popped 1 or 2 at a time in the toaster oven & they were delicious & perfect, slightly crispy on the outside (due to the flour maybe?) & nice & custard-y on the inside. My bf, who is waaay picky said he loved them & still talks about them. I also tried making this recipe with italian bread since the local store was sold out of french & they were not the same & the bf was not impressed. I really think the real french bread is the perfect texture for french toast, thus the name, french toast!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674149.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Egg / Milk Free Variation - Awesome!  My son has milk and egg allergies.  I followed the recipe but substituted rice milk for milk (Almond or Soy could be used also but Rice is sweeter) and I used a ground flax seed and water mixture as an egg substitute (1 tbl spoon ground flax to 3 tbl spoons water, whisk and let stand for a few minutes until thick, whisk again and use as egg).  I also used whole wheat flour instead of all purpose white.  It turned out great but I will use more cinnamon and vanilla in the future as the flax and ww flour neutralize the taste a little.  (I didn't use maple syrup with mine so would have liked more of the other flavors however my brother did use maple syrup and said is was fine as is).  WILL make this again!

text:
It's actually really good when you mix this recipe with the deep fried french toast recipe. I increased the milk to 1 1/2 cups, 1 tsp of ground cinnamon, 2 tsp of vanilla extract and used brown sugar instead of white. It was absolutely amazing because of the flour mixture and deep frying put it over the top. The southerner in me felt completely satisfied. Also I used the butter pecan syrup from ihop instead of regular maple syrup...talk about mouth explosion WOW! I will use this recipe everytime!

For years I wouldn't make french toast as it would never turn out correctly, always too wet (like an omelette with a piece of bread in the middle, would be a fair exaggeration). Very good....I used regular old white sandwich bread...I did add nutmeg because I love nutmeg and 1/2 tsp of butter flavoring.  I did not have AP flour so used self rising flour which made it more crispy over fluffy which is what we prefer. I got 13 servings instead of 12 maybe because my bread was thinner??? I will never make French Toast any other way. We are going to a remote cabin this weekend with friends and I am going to pre-make the batter to take with us.

text:
This was great-a nice way to keep french toast flavorful but not soggy! I did have a bit of an issue with clumps of flour-I think I just need a new whisk :P Luckily, flour clumps don't taste that bad ;) I added double the cinnamon to the mixture, then while the bread was soaking I sprinkled more on top and put that side down in the pan and sprinkled the other side before I flipped it. It made the appearance less even, but hopefully enhanced the flavor. I topped with powdered sugar and syrup. Delicious!

Absolutely amazing recipe! I have my husband grade the foods I cook for us on a 1-10 scale.  He gave this one a "9" & believe me he's honest about what he thinks, which I prefer he be or he'd end up eating his not so favorite foods again! Haha! One comment though I do have is that I scaled the recipe to 8 servings but used only 6 pieces of bread & had to skimp on the egg mixture for the 6th piece so I either soaked up too much egg or the recipe is a bit stingy with the amount allotted per piece of bread.  Otherwise, I thought the recipe was a definite keeper!!!

This french toast is soooooo good! The cinnamon is so delicious. I made a few variations to this recipe. I used a little more cinnamon, and since the recipe did not specify which bread to use, I used whole wheat. I also added a little more sugar in the better to compensate for the savoriness of the bread. Still this toast turned out so fluffy. definitely  a keeper. The only thing i am warning you about is to whisk in the ingredients in the order listed ( flour does not dissolve into eggs LOL)

text:
My family LOVED this recipe! I found mixing the dry ingredients together first kept the cinnamon from floating to the top. Also mixing the wet ingredients until its frothy kept the flour from sinking to the bottom. Other than that it tasted great, it was fluffy like the recipe said and I will be using this recipe again and again.

Thanks for helping me knock Sunday morning breakfast out of the park!

I used this Fluffy French Toast recipe along with another AllRecipes contributor Palsar7's Most Amazing Challah.

Wow, seriously.  Something about the two recipes together helped me channel Grand Ma, I know some of you know what I'm talking about.

Cooking food like this for your family and understanding the totality of what it means is some of what I enjoy most about my time in the kitchen.  Recipes like this help elevate my offerings.

Thanks you for posting and thank you to the others who reviewed this and shared their experiences with it, I found them to be quite valuable.

This is terrific!  I made it exactly as the recipe called... cooked on electric griddle (with lid on) at 325 for 5-6 min. a side (at least).

Kids said it was the best dinner ever... :D

This recipe was very good, although I didn't see much of a contrast from a regular French toast recipe. I used thick slices of challah bread, therefore more of the egg mixture was needed than the recipe stated.  The hints of the vanilla and cinnamon were not overpowering, so if you prefer a more highly-flavored French toast,  I would add additional flavorings.  This is a good basic French toast recipe.

text:
I used Italian bread that I sliced about 1/2 inch thick or so. My son likes cinnamon so we added 1/2 tablespoon.The vanilla I increased to 1 1/2 teaspoons. I added about 1/2 tablespoon of oil to  my electric skillet, spreading it with a folded paper towel, wiping the skillet after each batch was done. I also stirred the batter every once in a while. My kids said the same as a lot of people reviewed, they were fluffy! They  gave the recipe 5 stars. This will be the only way I make French toast from now on!

text:
I think this recipe really depends on the quality of the bread used.  I have used it with whole wheat and it was not as good as the big slices of texas toast, or leftover challah.  One tip: you need to do the ingredients in order - I didn't have enough, and added the egg too soon on the second batch my first time and it was very clumpy.  Never got all the flour incorporated.  I'd also recommend more cinnamon, if you want to actually taste it.  We couldn't.  A good french toast recipe overall, though.

While this certainly is not the most "gourmet" French toast recipe, it is very good bang-for-the-buck (as well as effort). We made it by the book, halving the recipe for the two of us and it turned out just fine.

text:
FABULOUS!!!! I made this with whole wheat challah bread instead of white and used evaporated milk (same amount as recipe calls for). I also added a dash of nutmeg and allspice. I thought it might be over- sweet, but these were so fluffy and moist. We didn't even need any syrup. PERFECT! I definitely recommend trying this with different breads. When using a thicker bread like challah, I found that 2 servings of the batter was needed for each thick slice. I.e. 6 servings made 3 slices.

text:
I loveeeeeee this recipe! I tried a different recipe without reading the reviews and it was a total soggy disaster. This recipe however was PERFECT and easy. I tried one bite and I got so distracted with how good it was that I burnt the second toast on the frying pan! I only used egg white since I had some leftover from something else I was baking. I sprinkled cinnamon on the side of the toast I would fry, and sprinkled more on the other side when flipping. That way, the cinnamon taste wouldn't be all soaked up in the first few slices of bread. Will definitely try it again.

Try it you will never go back to the old way!

This is most excellent french toast!  It's identical to my "go to" recipe, except for the flour.  However, I will be using this one in the future! Quite delicious! There were only two of us so I resized the proportions to make 4 slices, but then had to double the egg mixture to have enough moisture for all of the bread. My tip: use a large non-stick frying pan to avoid mushy slices.

text:
This was awesome french toast.  I followed the recipe exactly, but used 1/2 and 1/2 because we had some and used texas toast for the bread...it was perfect.  For me there is nothing worse than soggy french toast, and this had a nice crunch to the outside and great flavor.  Also, if you're like me and try mixing french toast batter with a fork...its worth the extra effort to get out the beaters for this so you don't end up with eggy spots.  I actually used an immersion blender and it worked great.

text:
Hubby rated a 4.5.  I let him rate it since he's the one who asked for french toast.  I cooked the first 5 on my griddle at 350' using nonstick spray, but they weren't as crispy as he would like, So on the the next 5 pieces, I used butter instead of spray, stayed at 350' on the griddle, then I put them in the toaster, and he said that made them a 5 star for him.  I had plenty of batter for them; I did not let them soak.  We will freeze the leftovers and throw them in the toaster when we have a hunger for them.  Thanks for a great recipe!

text:
I have several favourite French Toast recipes, and this one will now join the ranks. I halved the recipe to make it for three people, and used sliced 'Bread Machine Challah I' (from this site) which has an awesome texture, instead of white bread. After reading some of the reviews, I made some adjustments (based on another recipe I have) - I substituted dark brown sugar for the white, freshly grated nutmeg for the cinnamon and almond extract for the vanilla. I served the French Toast with a raspberry sauce, left over from the 'Brie Pecan Rollups with Raspberry Sauce' (again from this site) that I made for dinner last night. It was a real hit!

text:
This recipe was ok - my 3 girls loved it! I used 1 day old thick pieces of Challah. The French Toast did not fall apart at all. I added cinnamon to the batter, but next time i will sprinkle it on at the end. I like to see a lighter finished product and then sprinkle it with cinnamon and sugar or dip it into maple syrup. Update: - I made this recipe again and I used frozen pieces of bread and dipped that into the egg mixture and then fried it with a little bit of oil. That really helped to keep the bread from getting soggy and staying in one piece!

BRIDGET

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/206389.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
YUMMY!!!
Although this recipe is very close to the one I always use, this was better!!! I made breakfast for dinner last night and this recipe was a HIT!!! I think it was the vanilla extract and the flour. I added a dash of nutmeg along with more cinnamon than called for, (as other reviewers have done) and it was perfect. I scaled down the recipe to 6 servings (but it got all funny and called for 1  eggs how do you measure 1  eggs) So this is what I did, I used only 2 tablespoons of flour,  cup of half & half, 1 pinch of salt, 2 eggs,  teaspoon of cinnamon and  teaspoon nutmeg,  teaspoon of vanilla extract and 2 teaspoons of brown sugar. I then whisked it all together, but it was really really thick, so I added about 3 tablespoons of milk or so and continued to whisk it all together until it was thinner. I dipped the bread slices into the mixture and placed on a butter greased electric griddle. I cooked all 6 slices at the same time; they were crispy and golden brown when done. I had a little extra batter so I let a heel of the bread soak it all up and then cooked that up It was so good. This is my new French Toast Recipe!!! ! Thank you Bonnie!!!!

The only down side for me was that I half-ed the recipe thinking that would give me 6 pieces, but my bread was very absorpant and it got all sucked up in 4 pieces of bread.....next time I won't half all the wet ingrediants, just the bread. country:
None
text:
Good recipe. Only problem was the fact that I bought a Belgian Loaf that may not have been very good for soaking up the batter. On top of that, I made the mistake of not letting the thick slices sit long enough to do any real soaking. As a result, the batter was really only on the surface of the slices. It may be noted that had I done it right, there wouldn't have been enough batter for all of the slices. Suggest doubling the batter for this recipe.

This is definately a keeper!

text:
Just gone done making this for my husband who requested french toast for breakfest.  I thought it turned out pretty good, to be honest, I dont have french toast that often enough to know what 'normal' french toast would taste like.  I added a bit more white sugar and some nutmeg instead of cinnamon and almond extract instead of vanilla.  Flavor wise, I thought it was terrific.  Reminded me of holiday time, definetly a different flavor than the traditional cinnamon/vanilla, which I tend to use a lot in everyday baking.  The texture, meanwhile, was spongy.  Not in a bad way.  I used some fresh wheat bread for him, and some day-old slices of french bread for me, which I thought worked better since it sopped up more of the bread.  Not bad at all.  THanks.

text:
This recipe is the best french toast recipe ever! It is not coated in eggs like other recipes I've tried.  It makes the bread fluffy.  Just a few things: I use frozen bread to avoid soaking in the liquid too much, that way it is not soggy. I also use more cinammon (about 1.5 tsp).  Make sure you use good thick bread, D'Italiano bread is really good.  Also you can substitute the milk for some eggnog for some Christmas French Toast or use thick raisin bread for a twist.  Overall this is an incredible recipe - better than restaurants.

text:
The first time I made this I thought it was very good, but I like more cinnamon and sugar, so I used 2 teaspoons of cinnamon, 2 teaspoons of vanilla, and 2 tablespoons of sugar.  I have always made French toast very similar to this without the addition of the flour.  I LOVE the addition of the flour because it keeps most all of the cinnamon from floating to the top causing you to have to stir again and again before each 'dipping'.  Be sure to whisk the flour with some milk before adding all together. Thanks Bonnie, ya did good lady!

text:
This is the best french toast I've ever eaten!  I made it exactly as written, and had outstanding results.  I think the word "fluffy" may be misleading in this recipe.  I couldn't see any extra fluffiness, but the texture was thicker, making it "fluffy" i guess.  The flour really did help in this, and I didn't add baking powder.  I will be making all my french toast with flour from now on!!!  I've always just made basic french toast, but after trying this, it's just too well....basic!!!  Thanks so much for sharing this recipe Bonnie!!!!

text:
This recipe was very good, but not all that much better than others.  I think what may make a big difference is what type of bread you use and how it is cooked (i.e. veggie oil vs. butter).  Also, I would strain the batter so you don't get all the egg 'goop' that doesn't mix well with the rest of the batter ingredients.  
Thanks for the recipe - I'll continue to use it!

text:
16 yo son made it for Sunday brunch. Was a hit although he said it didnt have enough cinnamon, sugar and he soaked the bread to long. We all disagreed it was perfect, nothing was to overpowering, good balance. He used leftover French bread sliced thick and thick sandwich bread. I would suggest using your day old bread (like my son did) so that it wont get to soggy and fall apart when you try to transfer it to the griddle. There were no leftovers, recipe is a keeper.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
We think this recipe is awesome!  I doubled the entire recipe and it just was enough to use with an entire loaf of Texas toast.  I do add an extra 2 T of brown sugar (when doubling the recipe) and increase the cinnamon to 2 tsp (because we like the cinnamon taste), mix all the dry ingredients together first, then whisk in the milk, vanilla and eggs in slowly -  for me, it keeps the flour from settling at the bottom of the bowl as much after mixed.   I make with an entire loaf of Texas toast so we can have leftovers & freeze them - makes a perfect quick breakfast for the kid during the school week!  Thank you for the recipe - it's great!!

userID:
13980864
Display Name:
mommyto3nOK
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
10
favoritesCount:
45
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6105979.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
my family loved this recipe.  I took the advice of some reviews and doubled the cinnamon and vanilla.  my husband said the vanilla was too strong, so next time I wont double it.  also, I used 1 tbsp of brown sugar and 1 tbsp of white sugar as suggested by a reviewer, which I would do again.  i suggest mixing all dry ingredients in a separate bowl and mixing, then sift into the wet ingredients, whisking each time before you sludge toast in the mixture.  I made the mixture first without sifting the dry ingredients and it was clumpy and wouldnt whisk together.  using white texas toast is a must!  this will be my go to recipe for French toast.
Review:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good base. I tweaked just a bit. Doubled the recipe, b/c base was insufficient to coat 10 thick slices of bread. I did equal parts vanilla, sugar and cinnamon (used teaspoon). I melted butter on a cookie sheet and baked toast  in the oven on 375 for 17 - 20 mins, flipping the last 5 mins. The toast was golden brown, nice crunchy coating on the outside, soft and buttery on the inside. Yummmmmmmm.

I made the following changes to the recipe: - 2 tsp vanilla extract- 1/2 tsp nut meg- 2 tsp Cinnamon - brown sugar - cover while cooking (so the inside is cooked too) - heat medium low - make sure to really soaked the beard. It yields 8 fluffy delicious bread. Enjoy!

text:
Not everyone in my house appreciates the "eggy-ness" of french toast. I, however, love a good french toast when cooked all the way through. It requires good bread and a light hand when soaking. This recipe is perfect! French toast is always better with thicker bread, but even if you have a hard time with timing the soaking, your french toast will come out great!

text:
This was a great recipe! My whole family really enjoyed it. I did make  a few changes to the original recipe: added one tablespoon of brown sugar, doubled the vanilla, doubled the cinnamon. I then doubled the entire recipe to serve 6. It made one full loaf of regular white, day old bread. It was flavourful but not overly powerful. All the flavours blended well and I topped with a bit of butter, syrup and powdered sugar and ate it with bacon. Soooo good!

This is a good, basic French toast recipe.  I usually find that a scale using 1 egg is enough for 3 slices of bread, not 4.  Sometimes I cut the bread into 3 strips each to make French toast sticks.  In that case, it's more like 2.5 slices of bread per egg.

country:

text:
So I tried this recipe for my family today and I thought Id share our opinion since so many others are providing such negative reviews.
So, we made the recipe exactly as it is written, and, therefore, I can honestly offer an opinion.
First, I sent the older girls out to milk our Tibetan yak, Tianxia.  Weve had her several years, and we get all of our dairy from her.  She is totally free-range and her diet consists of what she can forage from around our 1600-acre farm in northern North Dakota.  It gives her milk a nutty, earthy flavor.  If there is anything we desire, its nutty AND earthy.
After the milking was done, and while we waited for the milk to settle and the cream to rise, the rest of us went to gather eggs from our flock of Arancana hens. The Arancana originates from Chile and lays beautiful blue eggs that have a dainty flavor that blends well with most foods.  Theyre a bit small, so it usually takes two to equal one typical, inferior, supermarket egg, so we had to double up on that part of the ingredient list.  Just like Tianxia, our little flock is also free-range which enhances their flavor with a certain terroir that can only be described to those of this place.
As a hobby, I have a small mail-order business that s

text:
Right up there with the best French toast we ever had!  I poured the liquid mixture into a 9x13 inch cake pan, laid  4 thick slices of Italian bread in the pan, turned them over a couple of times, then let them soak overnight. The 4 slices  absorbed all of the liquid but there was some gooey flour left behind in the pan. There was no problem with even distribution of the cinnamon when doing it this way.

userID:
2136962
Display Name:
Robert C.
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
5
favoritesCount:
576
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/814792.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was in charge of feeding a crowd of almost 200 people for breakfast, and the main course was French Toast.  Well most of us have the basic recipe we have learned from our folks; eggs, milk, cinnamon and vanilla.  I wanted something better that would really jazz up the meal, so I picked this one.  Very glad I did; it was a major hit!  I did follow the advice of a few readers and doubled the cinnamon and vanilla.  Was worried it would be too sweet but nope, came out just fine.   By doubling the recipe I was able to handle about 3 loaves of Texas bread per batch.  I agree with most... you have to wisk the batter each time you pick it up to add more bread to the mix.  And a medium heat is mandatory.. 300' tops.  It will help you cook the bread evenly and not soggy.  Thanks for the recipe, a keeper for sure!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2017-09-03T23:20:47.923
helpfulCount:
0

text:
The only change I made was that I added nutmeg and I mixed all the dry ingredients before combining with the wet. This recipe is perfect as is, best French toast I have ever made. Perfect and brown on the outside, nice and soft/moist/fluffy on the inside. Not dry at all and not at all soggy like some others have stated. My family was raving, even my picky son couldn't stop telling me how much he loved it. This recipe is a keeper for us!

Just a comment though and certainly not a deal breaker.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I am no cook but this made me look good on Mother's Day.

I did a couple things: I added 1/4 tsp of nutmeg based on suggestions and I used brioche bread for sweetness.

I whisked everything together and put it in a wide baking pan and put in each bread to soak for 10 minutes on one side and 10 on the other.  Do not over soak these or they will get soggy in the middle.  Ensure that the the bread is only half submerged.  Further, I used half butter and half vegetable oil for cooking - I found this to give the best golden colour and be very forgiving for first time cooks - ie. less prone to burning.

Wife and Mom loved it - making it for my nieces next!

text:
The toast turned out as I imagined. I did not have thick-cut toast on hand as I had freshly baked whole wheat bread from my local grocery store (and I used whole wheat flour in the recipe - the nutty flavor is deluxe). I was able to get eight slices soaked before running out of batter. Naturally, I whisked the batter after each session of bread soaking. I'm not that basic to not do otherwise. Also, I put my eggs through a sieve before whisking and adding them to my batter. This provided for a full-of-air batter that was delightful! This recipe is top notch!

The flour did not settle as much between each dip nor did the cinnamon separate. Will definitely keep this in my repertoire!

text:
This turned great.  I did not change anything, but did serve it with fresh, sweetened, whipped cream. That probably made up for extra sugar that people added.  Served it with ground cinnamon and ground cloves at the table for each person to sprinkle as they liked.  For bread, I used two day old French loaves cut into two inch thick slices.  It turned out nice and not even a little bit soggy. The combination of thick sliced French bread, sweet whipped cream, cinnamon, cloves, and pancake syrup almost had a cinnamon roll flavor.  Thumbs up! Thank you for the recipe!

text:
This was so yummy! Didn't change a thing, except (and I have no CLUE has this happened) but when I made it, it wasn't near enough egg mix for 12 slices of bread. Not sure if the OP was using smaller pieces or what, but I used Aunt Millie's 15 Grain bread (which made me feel super healthy haha) and they are admittedly bigger pieces but still....I could only get about seven really fluffy ones and one wimpy eighth piece that my toddler happily ate and was none the wiser. I will say that I did soak my bread in the egg mix longer as I like it very saturated; maybe that was the issue...either way I LOVED it and my family did as well! I will definitely be making this again. And next time, I will double recipe so I can have leftovers to freeze for later (as another poster mentioned) because leftovers of this stuff would make me very happy :)

Best french toast I've ever had.  We ran out of regular white sugar so I substituted with vanilla sugar and skipped the vanilla extract.  I also used a raisin egg-bread which added tiny bursts of sweetness to each bite.  I experimented with cooking times and you definitely want to cook the bread until you see dark patches so that it is cooked through, just don't let it burn.

text:
This French toast recipe is amazing!!! I found this recipe, and it's now the only one I use. Super quick and easy, makes delicious French toast. With almost every French toast recipe, I find that the outsides cook perfectly but often the centre is undercooked. I cook up each side, and then finish them off in the oven. Have them with some whipped cream and syrup and you're good to go!! This is an awesome recipe and I definitely recommend you try!!!

text:
This recipe def calls for thicker, denser bread. I converted the recipe to make only 4 servings (made 3 slices of regular sliced bread). I used wheat honey bread which was pretty soft. The first slice i let soak in the mixture and it turned out way too soggy in the middle, so i just dipped the 2nd and 3rd slices. overall the recipe is good and reliable but next time ill add more cinnamon and vanilla. i got most of the flavor from the syrup, bananas and powdered sugar i added. i will use this recipe again

Best French toast I've ever made. I follow the recipe exactly except for the type of bread. I've used thin-sliced white, regular white, Texas toast, whole wheat, French bread, cinnamon raisin bread...whatever I have on hand, and it's always great. This is a definite keeper, the only recipe I use now for "regular" French toast (not baked in the oven, etc.).

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3257782.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yummy! I mixed all my dry ingredients together first, then whisked the milk, eggs, and vanilla in and didn't notice a problem with cinnamon settling to the bottom. I did double the cinnamon. I use organic vanilla which has a strong presence...so I left it alone. I stored some in my freezer with wax paper in between slices and hope it all comes out well. I do advise on being careful on finding that balance on dipping or soaking the bread. You want enough to coat the bread, but not so much that you soak it and you rip it to shreds getting it from the bowl to the pan. Also ad a reviewer pointed out, be sure not to blaze it up and be in a hurry. If your bread had a good coating to it then it'll need to cook on med for a while so that you dont have nice crispy edges and a completely uncooked soggy middle...unless that's what ya like.  I'm a natural butter lover and used organic salted butter to cook my toast in...and I can say it looked burnt...but it tasted aaahhhhmazing. So if you want better presentation you could do as another reviewer suggested and use butter flavored crisco. 
Anyways...great recipe. I'll be holding onto this one.

Display Name:
WillofRose

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Topped it off with berries, whipped cream and powdered sugar-- Mm! Better than any dessert-style french toast I've ever gotten in a restaurant, that's for sure. Family adored it and thought so as well. I did take the advice of other reviewers and doubled the vanilla, sugar and cinnamon, however. I feel like phrase "soak bread slices in mixture until saturated" might be taken the wrong way-- I took it to mean 'soak it for a few seconds' and the already pretty squishy and somewhat thinly pre-sliced bread totally fell apart, ahaha. (Still tasted great though!).  If you have the same kinda bread, just quickly dip them as fully in the mix and get them out and onto the pan ASAP, or else they'll fall apart or be too soggy. I also recommend that you whisk the mixture before you soak a new piece of bread every time, as the cinnamon tends to float to the top when left alone for awhile, and might all go on a single piece of bread upon touching the surface.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

This is a great recipe!   I followed it exactly, using stale Sunbeam TexToast bread.  The toast turns out exactly how we like it: fluffy and crispy, but soft and just slightly gooey in the middle. Awesome french toast! I did change a few things though. I substituted French bread and sliced it 1" thick the night before and left it on a cookie rack overnight to dry out. text:
The flavor was excellent and added brown sugar as another rating suggested. 
I have to give it 4 stars for the reason if you use Texas toast (as the recipe calls for or a thick sliced bread) it will barely do 6 slices. You would have to double to do 12. 
 I did not over soak since the bread will only absord so much and it was well drained off each slice before placing on griddle. Took only 12-15 min to cook at 300 degrees. 20 min would have been overdone.

city:
