region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very nice recipe as is; however, I do modify it a bit.  One thing I do is to substitute regular vanilla extract for McCormick Vanilla Nut flavoring; just gives a kick of flavor.  The second thing I do is add ground nutmeg (equal to the amount of cinnamon), and then keep sprinkling more cinnamon and nutmeg into the batter as I dip more bread, as it tends to pull those two items out pretty quickly.  Other than that, I butter my finished toasts, dust with powdered sugar, and just enough syrup to cover the toast.

text:
Good recipe for my signature French toast. 

3-4 oz. lemon curd creamed together with a softened package cream cheese. 2 lbs. strawberries macerated over night. Whipped cream (about 1/2+  pint heavy cream, sugar, vanilla etc. optional). (The kids like banana extract)

Pile up the toast with a smear of cream cheese mixture between each slice(it will melt), cover in strawberry goodness with whipped cream on top. 

It's really filling!

text:
I saw this French Toast recipe in my email and I am a huge sucker for French Toast.  My original recipe is just eggs and a little bit of milk whisked together.  I have been using this recipe for more than 20 years .  After seeing this other recipe, I wanted to make it instantly.

Now for starters it was very easy to make and took me about 5 minutes or less to make this fabulous French Toast batter.  I just watch the video and followed the written recipe.  

I used regular whole grain bread instead of thick bread, because that is what I had.  The batter smelled terrific and after dipping and placing the bread on griddle, the nice cinnamon and vanilla aroma that came into the kitchen was just awesome.  Now,  I am one not for cinnamon in or on my french toast, but  with the vanilla in the batter, the cinnamon was not strong for me.

So after cooking the french toast and placing it on the plate, the smell was so good i couldn't wait to dig in.  I did lightly butter the  french toast  and drizzle lightly with maple syrup.  The first taste I got was the vanilla taste and later the cinnamon.  The french toast was so good, I would definitely make this again .

I have made this French Toast for years. It always comes out fluffy  and tasty. A few key things are essential to this; use thick slice French bread or Texas Toast bread, more cinnamon as needed, and fry until fully golden brown on both sides. The flavor of the egg does come through and the combination of all the ingredients creates a special breakfast taste treat. It doesn't have to be limited to breakfast though.

text:
Very good.  Easy to make.  It's great for cheap breads Wonder Bread and Schwebel's.  The flour adds mass while staying light and fluffy.

I used a half tablespoon of butter to oil the pan.  With the flour in the egg wash, it gave the toast a nice crispy corner.  I also add a sprinkle of powdered sugar and whatever fresh fruit I have on hand (bananas, blackberries, blueberries, strawberries, etc.).

This was a really good recipe, My family said it was the best French toast I have ever made in my life ( and I have made a lot of French toasts). The only exception is that I used self rising flour instead of all purpose ( I didn't have any all purpose flour on hand) but it still turned out good. I only gave it 4 stars because it still had that weird taste like the flour - egg mixture was peeling off the bread, but other than that, it was the best french toast I have ever tasted!!!

This turned out great! I used coconut oil for frying.  I poured half of the egg mixture into a 9x13 dish, soaked 6 of the bread slices, flipped them and soaked again, then fried them.  I let the remaining 6 slices soak while I cooked the first 6.  I was able to make 12 slices with Texas toast with no problem.

I added some nutmeg with the cinnamon and topped with banana and whipped cream. I used Kings Hawaiian sliced bread which absorbed more batter than expected. Total yield was only 6 slices. If using this bread do not dip in batter too long. It quickly falls apart.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe produced perfect, restaurant-style french toast for us. I doubled it, and used a full loaf of Texas toast (17 slices). I made it the night before, cooled on wire racks, then stored in fridge for a quick Easter morning reheat in the toaster and it was still beautiful and crispy. My only alteration was to double the amount of cinnamon and add brown sugar in equal proportion to the white sugar. I whisked the dry ingredients together before adding the milk and fried in a combination of half butter, half butter flavored crisco.  This is our new keeper!  Thank you!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wonderful recipe! The only change I make is I don't add the cinnamon to the mixture. Instead, I put the cinnamon in a little sifter and dust it over the bread while it's in the pan cooking. You'll need to quickly wipe the pan clean with a paper towel between slices of bread, but I think this is the best way to get an even distribution of cinnamon on all slices of bread. This way I don't need to be worried about the cinnamon rising to the top of the bowl.

text:
I love this recipe! I make it with lactose free milk and it really does taste like the French toast I get at my favorite breakfast restaurant just without the terrible stomach ache after.  If you're going to make this recipe Make sure you remember to stir the batter before every new dip of bread and make sure your griddle is greased constantly. I just spray some Pam after every slice and that prevents those ugly black burns and the egg mixture sticking.

text:
This recipe has stellar flavor. I was concerned when I saw clumps of cinnamon in the batter, but I stirred it once more and it was amazing. I used ordinary wheat bread, but next time I will try to make homemade bread and cut it thickly. When you dip the bread in the mixture, make sure you saturate it until it is dripping. Since my bread was cut thin, I could used 18 pieces. Enjoy!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5732509.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this french toast recipe with home made challah bread. Cook several slices and figure out how much soaking in the batter is to your liking. You may want a custardy french toast (longer soak) or a drier french toast (less soak, more of a drag through and grill).  I have never made French toast with flour in the mixture, but it really makes it work.  Make sure you whisk each time you dip your bread. The flour and cinnamon together sink to the bottom.

text:
Really delicious recipe!  However, I found that the egg mixture wasn't quite enough for that much bread.  I tried to make enough mixture for 8 pieces of bread, but could only coat 6.  That being said, I did leave one piece of bread in there to soak for a minute or two, and that piece soaked up a lot!  If you're saturating the bread instead of just dipping it, you'll need more egg mixture.  I also like another reviewer's idea of sprinkling cinnamon right onto the bread.  I whisked after each slice and still ran out of cinnamon in the mix.

text:
This came out fantastic! Just as moist and delicious as I had hoped.  

I followed the recipe exactly and it was wonderful! I used plain whole wheat sandwich bread because it was the only type I had on hand, and usually that means sub-par French toast, but this came out amazingly.  Who knew a little flour was the only difference between dry French toast and delicious slices of perfection??

One thing-I only rated this 4 stars because as is, the egg mixture didn't make enough for 12 bread slices. I was planning on freezing the extras for later breakfasts, but I only got 6 slices out the mixture. Next time I will double it so I can have leftovers :)

text:
This was the 1st time I've ever made French toast in my life and it was a hit with the family. I substituted soy milk for the regular milk since I'm allergic to anything with milk protein. I also substituted brown sugar for white sugar. I pretty much followed everything else to a "T". And ofcourse i topped it off with powdered sugar. I used white Texas toast. Soaked it in the mixture and put it in a hot skillet that had oil and butter in it.  I lowered the heat to cook it slower so the inside would be cooked as well.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Love this recipe! I double the vanilla extract and cinnamon, also added a tablespoon of brown sugar. It seemed to be what everyone suggested and they were right, it was perfect and fluffy. Make sure to stir the mixture every time before you soak the toast because the cinnamon will float to the bottom of the bowl. Also soak the bread on each side don't just dunk it in real quick, I normally let it sit 20-30 sec on each side in the mixture. I used one of those Italian loaves of bread from the Wal-Mart bakery and it worked really well.

None
text:
I have been using this recipe all my life pretty much. Came up with it after I didn't like other french toast recipes. I never have measured it out (I'm not the type who ever really measures lol) I just eyeball it so I'm glad someone else has done the hard part for me so I can share it easier lol. The only thing I do differently is I sometimes add a little baking flour to help it be even fluffier and when I'm in the mood I'll sometimes add maple syrup right to the batter and skip plates and forks for grab and go yummy fluffy maple french toast! Thank you for sharing this, now I can share my awesome french toast recipe with my friends who have asked! :-)

text:
I used regular white bread and began by following the directions exactly.  The bread became so saturated that it fell apart in the batter.  Scooped up the remains and patted them together on the griddle and turned the heat way down - about 2 on an electric stove.  

The batter only lasted for five slices, not the twelve in the recipe.  The bread which fell apart eventually toasted well enough to eat, did not notice any flavor.

Prepared the rest of the slices by increasing the amount of egg and vanilla.  

This recipe didn't work for me, but maybe with thick Texas toast it would.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The addition of flour is GENIUS. Who knew something so simple would be so effective in achieving (or rather maintaining, as I find my past attempts at french toast tend to 'deflate' as they cool) the fluffiness. I made this recipe as is (with the exception of a dash of nutmeg), although I found 1/2 the recipe was sufficient for 3/4 of a loaf of challah bread (plenty for two people). In the future, I will plan on tweaking the recipe (i.e. adding a little more vanilla, using half-n-half instead of milk, adding a dash of OJ with orange zest grand marnier as one reviewer suggested, etc.). Definitely adding this recipe to my brunch repertoire.

text:
This tasted pretty good...but as written, a three-star is about all I can give here.  I made it as written (as I usually like to do the first time...because you can't really review a recipe if you change it).  This made only 8 pieces for me, and not 12.  I also think it could use some more cinnamon and maybe some more vanilla.  I will probably make this again and make those changes and plan for only 8 pieces...because after wiping off the excess mixture and still not getting the number I expected, I was disappointed.

Just tried this and it's amazing! I used Van de Kamp's French toast bread. I added 1/8 tsp of nutmeg to the batter (personal preference). My roommate generally doesn't like sweet things but he cleaned his plate and went back for seconds! Will definitely make again.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great french toast recipe.  To prevent ingredients seperating - I first mix all dry ingredients, then beat in the eggs till smooth and add the cup of milk last.  The cinnamon and flour are perfectly blended that way and, with no seperating.  Also, I add quite a bit more cinnamon (probabaly a tablespoon).  Almost any kind of bread works great - normally I use a french or italian loaf bread sliced in two and thoroughly drenched in the mix, then slowly cooked in a covered skillet so the middle isn't soppy.  Great stuff!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This makes very good, classic french toast.  Due to my husband's food allergy, I made a gluten-free version using gluten-free bread ("Udies" brand) & gluten-free flour ("Bob's Red Mill" brand) and it turned out just fine. I do believe that your results will vary depending on what type of bread you use. I used whole grain bread (gluten-free) and it wasn't as fluffy as I would imagine it would've been had I used a wheat-based bread -- I think a brioche would be wonderful & I will try that in the future (and will edit this review to reflect that).  I also reduced the sugar slightly, as it was plenty sweet when served with syrup. With that said, it was still delicious as a gluten-free french toast and we were very pleased with the results.  I will keep this in my family recipe binder as my go-to french toast.
Review:

text:
Really liked this recipe!  The toast was nicely crisp when cut into with a fork and creamy on the inside.  I did up the sugar and vanilla a bit but that was the only change made.  I used high maize flour to up the fiber content. I used my own homemade, whole grain bread sliced nice and thick. I tripled the recipe and used a whole loaf of bread.  I froze the leftovers and they reheated nicely in the toaster. This recipe is a keeper!

text:
I was skeptical about this recipe--it sounded like soaking your bread in thin cookie dough before cooking--but it turned out great! The addition of flour is genius, it really eliminates the sogginess that most French Toast recipes have. In the future, I think I'll increase both the vanilla and cinnamon to bump up the flavor, but otherwise it's a great recipe!

userID:
7268400
Display Name:
pwinfy
isPro:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614284.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are my favorite breakfast go-to! Make them the night before and freeze for a quick breakfast. I used Challa bread and do cut them thick. I do soak the bread in the batter as the areas where I didn't fully soak (edges usually), I could tell they were not moist as the others but crunchy like stale bread. I used 1Tbs of white sugar and 1/2tbs of brown sugar. Doubled the vanilla and cinnamon. The cinnamon does get taken from the batter after the first few toast are dipped so I would sprinkle a little cinnamon on the rest while they are cooking. If you are taking them out from the freezer, reheat in the microwave for just 1min 30 seconds - 2 minutes for 2 french toasts. I cover it with powdered sugar and light maple syrup.
Review:

Excellent though I tweaked it just a bit. I added extra cinnamon, a healthy dollop of Mild Molasses and used 3 packets of Stevia in place of the sugar. I'll drop that to 2 packets next go-'round and give 'er a go. With the addition of the Molasses that may be all that's needed. Both white and wheat bread taste good with this recipe but I was only able to get six slices coated but that's more than enough for the two of us.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I always wanted to make french toast, so I decided to use this recipe as my first time. It was the most delicious french toast I've ever tried! My husband wouldn't stop raving about it. I did make some changes though. I customized it to make 4 servings instead of the original 12 (just for my husband and I). It asked for 1 tbl and 1 tsp of flour. I added 1tbl and 1/2 tbl instead, just to make it thicker. Also, I fried these using melted butter instead of oil. As I was frying them, I sprinkled cinnamon on both sides, to give it that extra hint of cinnamon. These came out prefect!

This is very tasty.  Only my last piece of bread turned out fluffy because I let it soak while the others were cooking, so that's the key, let it soak for a few seconds.  All the toast tasted nice, even the ones that were flat like regular French toast.  I will be using this recipe to introduce French toast to my English/French fiance, because he's never had it and I think this one is perfect, not too eggy.  Also, I added lots of cinnamon!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe as-is and I didn't find that the flour made the french toast fluffier, either. And I don't see how flour would do that without some additional leavening. However, I used multigrain bread and I would probably had a different result with something less dense. The flavor was good but not exceptional and I didn't a dozen pieces out of it, either.  Some suggestions: combine all ingredients in the blender to eliminate the lumps, and replace the sugar with orange marmalade and the milk with buttermilk for more depth of flavor.

text:
I used Challah, and substituted 1/2 cup flavored liquid coffee creamer for 1/2 cup milk, added a dash of almond extract, and used pumkin pie spice instead of the cinn.  My husband enjoyed it. I didn't see a difference in the addition of the flour, but that could have been due to the add'l creaminess of the flavored creamer and also the dense challah I used.  I also used other reviewers tips for cooking with the butter flavored crisco and that worked well for not getting overly brown by the last batch. Kept the early batches warm in the oven while the other batches cooked.

text:
This is delicious!  I used fresh french bread sliced diagonally about 1-1/4 " thick I used my thumb as a gauge from end of nail to knuckle).  Let the bread soak up all of the batter before frying.  I pan fried it in butter and served with real maple syrup.  Like another reviewer, I added, oh, maybe a 1/2 teaspoon of almond extract with the vanilla (for 3 servings). I also added a bit more sugar.  This is a wonderful recipe that I enjoyed making and eating. Oh yes, and my husband said he could smell it outside of the house and it smelled yummy!

region:

country:
None
text:
This is really easy to make even if you don't do it perfectly or if you made a little change. The flour really ads something nice. You notice a little more fluff as you eat but you don't really think of flour unless you know it's in there. I find I need more of the mixture then the recipe indicates so I made a little extra. I also find that the bigger the pieces of bread the better. Really yummy overall and easy to whip up. My favorite french toast from this site so far and I have tried about 5 of the most popular.

I used this recipe yesterday and it was the first time I ever made homemade french toast. It went over very well, even with the picky 3 and 6 year olds. It was extremely easy to make and the only change I made was that I added a splash of orange juice to the mix. I used Texas Toast and there was not enough of the mixture, so when using very thick bread, I would suggest preparing the mix for a larger number of servings.

text:
Great french toast - I made it with country wheat and it turned out great!  Be sure to get a good soak on the bread, not just an outside coating (be gentle after soaking!).  Try a taste before adding additional butter and syrup on top once serving - the french toast is very tasty (and sweet enough in my opinion) without additional syrup.  I'm also not a fan of loading up on butter if not really needed for taste..

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was very good!  I never follow a recipe.  My changes for this recipe were very slight though.  I used Texas Toast (made 8 slices perfectly, no leftovers) and we love cinnamon so I sprinkled extra cinnamon on the tops of the toast before flipping them.  I made a fruit topping in a saucepan over low to med. heat by combining approx. one tsp. butter, one T. brown sugar, one tsp. water, some sliced apricots, peaches, and a banana that i added just before turning off the stove. The flavor resembled cobbler.  The toast was also good on it's own.  Hope you enjoy it as much as we did.

text:
My DH made this french toast for breakfast this morning and it was very good.  He followed the recipe exactly, but we scaled it to 8 servings (which made 5 slices of french toast using regular whole grain bread).  The only slight modification he made was to add a bit of nutmeg, and it was delicious with this addition.  In the end, we both agree that the only way to serve this french toast is with fresh strawberries, whipped cream and real maple syrup...Yummy!!!

I tried this recipe this morning and I loved it!  My husband is a french toast fanatic and after nine months of cooking it while pregnant with my first son, I couldn't eat it anymore, that was five years ago.  French toast has made a comeback.  For those who rated this recipe bland, get a little creative!  I added xtra sugar, brown sugar, vanilla, cinniman, and some nutmeg.  Thanks for a family favorite!

text:
This was quick and easy to make, and it used typical household ingredients. I followed the recipe exactly after after a few minutes on the griddle, it firmed up and looked great. 

It did seem as though the recipe was missing something -- a touch of sweetness  or moistness. I also think the 7-grain bread I had on hand was not the greatest match for this recipe.

One serving note: If you let the bread "saturate" as the recipe instructs, it won't make quite as many servings says.

I don't usually eat french toast because of the egg taste.  But this was light and fluffy and I sliced my pieces like FT sticks!

text:
I was pleased with the results of this recipe.  The results were on the order of French Toast that I've had at up-scale restaurants, not at all like French Toast at Grandma's house...which is to say that there was not a lot of egg mixture hanging off the toast, and it didn't have what I would consider a traditional taste and texture.  I added 1/4tsp Nutmeg and used fresh baked white bread sliced approx 1 inch thick.  There was only enough egg mixture to prepare 8 slices.
